Hey dev friends!

I've been working on a little side project that's finally starting to take shape, and I wanted to share it with you first, since it's still in prototype mode. I actually worked out some final bugs this morning, so there's a GOOD chance it might still error out on you, haha! But that's why I'm sharing it with my fellow devs as it’s not quite ready for civilian use yet. :sweat_smile:

<https://cro-ai-72462d843a7b.herokuapp.com/|Check out the app here>!

*How to Use It:*

Enter the URL of a website or landing page, and behind the scenes, it will take a screenshot of the page and send it to *OpenAI’s Vision API*. The AI will analyze the screenshot and give *conversion rate optimization feedback* based on a set of CRO principles that I’ve trained it on. These are the same optimization rules I use when consulting my website clients—so it’s basiclly like having a mini-consultation with an AI version of me! :smile:

I originally got inspired to build this when OpenAI came out with their <https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/vision|Vision API>. If you're not familiar, GPT-4o, GPT-4o mini, and GPT-4 Turbo all have vision capabilities now so they can analyze images -- now they can "see." which is also kinda scary but it got me thinking: *what if AI could visually analyze a website and give CRO feedback*, just like I do with clients?

What started as a simple idea turned out to be a bit more complex than I thought, but it’s been really fun (and quite a learning experience)!

*Tech Stack:*
• *Vue.js* on the frontend: my fav JS framework for building interactive UIs.
• *Node.js/Express* backend: Node for running JavaScript on the server, Express as the web app framework.
• *Heroku* for hosting
• *Puppeteer* for screenshots: Headless browser for capturing website screenshots.
• *Redis* and *Bull* for job queuing: Redis stores the job data, Bull manages the job queue and worker processes.
I originally didn't plan to use Redis and Bull, but I ran into *rate limits on Heroku*. Between capturing screenshots and waiting for OpenAI to process them, longer websites sometimes took more than 30 seconds to complete—pushing me past Heroku’s 30-second timeout limit. So, I had to set up a job queuing system to handle this smoothly. This was a unexpected bump in the road but actually made me a better developer, forcing me to learn how to manage complex workflows in a more scalable way!

What's Next:
Right now, this is a barebones MVP—just wanted to get the idea out of my head and into the world. Some next steps I’m thinking about:
• Improving the UI so users don’t need to select which type of page they’re optimizing.
• Not sure how I’ll monetize this yet. :man-shrugging: Maybe I’ll offer it as a free tool to my HubSpot theme customers, or as a lead gen tool for my agency (eg: HubSpot’s website grader) Who knows, maybe I’ll sell it to an agency or a company like SEMrush and add it to their toolset. The possibilities are endless!
Let me know what you think—I’m open to feedback!
